title: Blizzard is giving us Vanilla, time for Riot to give us URF
body: You think we don't but we do because contrary to public belief players do in fact know what they want, and are the reason you make any money at all.

Vanilla servers on WoW are comparable to asking for a season 2 game mode or something for League.  They are not comparable to a game mode that was meant to be temporary, and was never meant to be as big of a hit as it was.

Btw, there was no data on how long they measured whether players came back or not. Maybe not by the time the study was complete, but players come and go all the time because there hasn't been a healthy meta in this game for YEARS. Each meta drives players away. URF is an escape where you can get together with your buddies and roll on the floor laughing out of enjoyment, the game has lost that aspect. URF was never intended for you solo players. It was intended for a group to have crazy adventures.

That Vanilla server is going to implode, and I'm going to laugh the whole time.

No one actually *liked* the game in Vanilla, they liked the community aspect and all that. Once people clear MC a few times, they'll get plenty bored with how little there is to do in the game at that point.

###### Now, if they made a Wrath, Cata or MoP server... that'd be hugely popular.

>No one actually liked the game in Vanilla, they liked the community aspect and all that. Once people clear MC a few times, they'll get plenty bored with how little there is to do in the game at that point.

The fact that a vanilla private server had thousands of players (and was in fact the impetus for Blizzard to finally make one) before getting shut down by lawyers directly contradicts this. [150,000 active players, actually.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nostalrius).

This is free money for Blizzard. A version of the game that they don't have to ever update and only pay to keep the servers running (and in the age of VM's, that's a lot easier than it used to be) and handle the occasional GM request. If only half of those private server folks make the jump, that's $1.1M every single month in subscription fees.
